liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise â€” a "concept paper." The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site. In its report, the Intelligence Ministry â€” a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy â€” offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war." The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security. The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor. A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering. The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli ministry drafts plan to transfer Gaza civilians to Egypt

children.content: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise â€” a "concept paper."

props.alt: People walk through rubble in ruined streets.

children.content: (AP Photo: Abed Khaled)
The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site.

In its report, the Intelligence Ministry â€” a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy â€” offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war."
The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security.
The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor.
A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering.
The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities". "Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks. The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas. "So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel envoy wears yellow star at UN, accuses Security Council of 'staying silent'

children.content: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities".

props.alt: Gilad Erdan sits at a table wearing a yellow star of David reading "Never Again"

children.content: (AP Photo: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez )

"Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks.
The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas.
"So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions". The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it". He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating. Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas". Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Immediate ceasefire 'a matter of life and death'

children.content: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions".
The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it".

He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating.
Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas".
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: QFES has called today's fire conditions "immensely challenging". It said the situation at Tara is of most concern - 115 firefighters and 28 trucks are on the ground, supported by heavy machinery and several aircraft. "Our number one focus is protecting lives and keeping communities safe. "Please heed the warnings for your area and stay up-to-date with local information, as situations can change rapidly in these conditions."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, helped by gains in energy and financial stocks, while traders awaited the US central bank's policy meeting this week for further interest rate clues. The ASX 200 index advanced 0.3 per cent or 20 points, to 6,793 by 1:37pm AEDT after hitting a more than one-year low on Monday. The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave policy rates on hold at the end of its two-day meeting starting later in the day. Market participants will focus on the message from Fed policymakers to gauge the interest rate outlook. Meanwhile, retail sales in Australia rose at the fastest pace in eight months in September, suggesting resilience in consumer spending which would add to the case for an interest rate hike at the Australian central bank's policy meeting on November 7. Investors are also looking out for a survey of purchasing managers in China's manufacturing segment later in the day to assess the economic recovery of Australia's top trading partner. A Reuters poll showed China's manufacturing activity likely expanded for a second straight month in October. In Sydney, interest rate-sensitive financials rose 0.7 per cent, with the big four banks gaining between 0.5 per cent and 0.7 per cent. Energy stocks jumped 0.3 per cent, with Woodside Energy and Santos up 0.8 per cent and 0.9 per cent, respectively. Technology stocks tracked their Wall Street peers higher, gaining 0.1 per cent. Shares of Xero jumped 0.3 per cent. Gold stocks slid 1.3 per cent, with miner Northern Star Resources losing 2.7 per cent. Among individual stocks, Origin Energy fell 0.6 per cent after superannuation fund AustralianSuper said it plans to vote against a Brookfield-led consortium's $US9.78 billion takeover offer for the company. In corporate news, winemaker Treasury Wine agreed to a $US900 million buyout of California's DAOU Vineyards. Trading in its shares was halted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX is still tracking higher in afternoon trade

children.content: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, helped by gains in energy and financial stocks, while traders awaited the US central bank's policy meeting this week for further interest rate clues.
The ASX 200 index advanced 0.3 per cent or 20 points, to 6,793 by 1:37pm AEDT after hitting a more than one-year low on Monday.

The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave policy rates on hold at the end of its two-day meeting starting later in the day. Market participants will focus on the message from Fed policymakers to gauge the interest rate outlook.

Meanwhile, retail sales in Australia rose at the fastest pace in eight months in September, suggesting resilience in consumer spending which would add to the case for an interest rate hike at the Australian central bank's policy meeting on November 7.

Investors are also looking out for a survey of purchasing managers in China's manufacturing segment later in the day to assess the economic recovery of Australia's top trading partner. A Reuters poll showed China's manufacturing activity likely expanded for a second straight month in October.
In Sydney, interest rate-sensitive financials rose 0.7 per cent, with the big four banks gaining between 0.5 per cent and 0.7 per cent.
Energy stocks
Â
jumped 0.3 per cent, with Woodside Energy
Â
and Santos up 0.8 per cent and 0.9 per cent, respectively.
Technology stocks tracked their Wall Street peers higher, gaining 0.1 per cent. Shares of Xero jumped 0.3 per cent.
Gold stocks slid 1.3 per cent, with miner Northern Star Resources losing 2.7 per cent.

Among individual stocks, Origin Energy fell 0.6 per cent after superannuation fund AustralianSuper said it plans to vote against a Brookfield-led consortium's $US9.78 billion takeover offer for the company.
In corporate news, winemaker Treasury Wine agreed to a $US900 million buyout of California's DAOU Vineyards. Trading in its shares was halted.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has warned that there could be "a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility" in the years ahead. In a speech on emerging threats to financial stability on Tuesday, RBA assistant governor Brad Jones said supply shocks, a higher and more volatile bond term premium, and reduced smoothing from price-insensitive buyers were the potential contributing factors to a structurally higher interest rate volatility, despite that much of the past two decades saw long-term interest rate volatility either decline or languish at unusually subdued levels. He said a period of structurally higher interest rate volatility would present several challenges to financial system stability. "Banks of all sizes will have to manage overall duration risk more intently," Mr Jones said. "Over much of the past few decades, growth in incomes consistently exceeded the level of interest rates. This dampened credit risks for lenders. But debt servicing among borrowers with high debt levels will be more challenging â€“ and credit risks will increase as a result â€“ in an environment where interest rates periodically exceed the growth in incomes. "The post-GFC era of exceptionally low interest rate volatility gave rise to a new generation of investment business models and strategies. "It remains to be seen how market functioning could be affected in a regime of higher inflation and interest rate volatility, including where open-end fixed-income funds encounter liquidity stress, margining is more tightly enforced than in the past, and broker-dealers are unable or unwilling to supply liquidity."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA warns of 'a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility'

children.content: The Reserve Bank has warned that there could be "a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility" in the years ahead.
In a speech on emerging threats to financial stability on Tuesday,
RBA assistant governor Brad Jones

said supply shocks, a higher and more volatile bond term premium, and reduced smoothing from price-insensitive buyers were the potential contributing factors to a structurally higher interest rate volatility, despite that much of the past two decades saw long-term interest rate volatility either decline or languish at unusually subdued levels.
He said a period of structurally higher interest rate volatility would present several challenges to financial system stability.
"Banks of all sizes will have to manage overall duration risk more intently," Mr Jones said.

"Over much of the past few decades, growth in incomes consistently exceeded the level of interest rates. This dampened credit risks for lenders. But debt servicing among borrowers with high debt levels will be more challenging â€“ and credit risks will increase as a result â€“ in an environment where interest rates periodically exceed the growth in incomes.
"The post-GFC era of exceptionally low interest rate volatility gave rise to a new generation of investment business models and strategies.

"It remains to be seen how market functioning could be affected in a regime of higher inflation and interest rate volatility, including where open-end fixed-income funds encounter liquidity stress, margining is more tightly enforced than in the past, and broker-dealers are unable or unwilling to supply liquidity."
